Literature Review: The psychology of entrepreneurship has garnered significant attention over the past decade, with researchers delving into the intricate dynamics that drive entrepreneurial actions and processes. This literature review synthesizes recent findings, focusing on the interplay between action and process within the entrepreneurial context. We employ the action theory process model of entrepreneurship as a guiding framework, exploring theories of action and adopting a process perspective to understand the antecedents of entrepreneurial actions. Theories of action, such as effectuation/causation, bricolage, the theory of planned behavior, and action theory, provide foundational insights into how entrepreneurs make decisions and navigate uncertainty. Effectuation, as proposed by Sarasvathy (2001), emphasizes a flexible, means-oriented approach to decision-making, contrasting with the goal-oriented causation approach. Bricolage, introduced by Baker and Nelson (2005), highlights the resourcefulness of entrepreneurs in leveraging available resources creatively. The theory of planned behavior (Ajzen, 1991) offers a framework for understanding how attitudes, subjective norms, and perceived behavioral control influence entrepreneurial intentions and actions. Action theory (Frese & Zapf, 1994) further elucidates the cognitive processes underlying goal-directed behaviors in entrepreneurship. From a process perspective, the antecedents of entrepreneurial actions—cognition, motivation, and emotion—are examined in terms of their development and recursive relationships over time. Cognitive processes, such as opportunity recognition and decision-making, are crucial in shaping entrepreneurial actions (Baron, 2006). Motivation, encompassing both intrinsic and extrinsic factors, drives entrepreneurs to initiate and persist in their ventures (Shane et al., 2003). Emotions, including passion and fear, play a dual role in influencing entrepreneurial behavior, both as drivers and as outcomes of the entrepreneurial process (Cardon et al., 2012). The dynamic nature of these antecedents and their interactions with actions underscore the complexity of the entrepreneurial journey. Recursive relationships between actions and their antecedents highlight the iterative and evolving nature of entrepreneurship, where actions influence cognition, motivation, and emotion, which in turn shape subsequent actions (McMullen & Shepherd, 2006). This review concludes that the action theory process model serves as a valuable framework for explaining the psychological dynamics of entrepreneurship, offering a comprehensive lens through which to view the interplay between action and process. Future research directions include exploring the longitudinal development of entrepreneurial actions and their antecedents, as well as the role of context in shaping these dynamics.
